answer.text: No: no culture can impose its values on any other culture, even if those values promote human well-being.

questiontext.text: According to Feuerbach, religion has played a significant role in human history by pointing out how human existence aspires to what it has not yet achieved. answer.text: the infinite, positive counterpart to Satan and the forces of evil.
the source of human existence and the inspiration to human endeavors.
the cause of human suffering and thus the reason why we must rely only on ourselves.
the infinite extension of humanity, idealized and alienated from our essence.

questiontext.text: According to Marx, religion is "the opium of the masses" insofar as religious beliefs:

create in us a mentality that we are not individuals in God's eyes, only human masses.
desensitize us to the human misery caused by social structures we should change.

questiontext.text: This philosopher argued that "nothing" ( not-being) cannot exist by the following line of reasoning. To speak of a thing, one has to speak of a thing that exists. As a corollary, there can be no such things as coming-into-being, passing-out-of-being or not-being.

Metaphysics attempts to provide a rational explanation for why things in nature are the way that they are. This is different from a mythic explanation, insofar as myth provides:

Suppose that human well-being is the correct standard for evaluating ethical theories and judgments. Would this mean that we have to reject the cultural relativist's claim that each culture has a right to decide its own values?

answer.text: No: no culture can impose its values on any other culture, even if those values promote human well-being.
No: all cultures are different in what they value (indeed, that is what makes them different in the first place); so the destruction of cultural differences would mean the end of cultures.
Yes: but each culture would have to decide whether "promoting well-being" for its members is really what it wants.
Yes: any culture that would not satisfy basic material and social needs of all of its members would not be as good as it should be.

answer.text: the infinite, positive counterpart to Satan and the forces of evil.
the source of human existence and the inspiration to human endeavors.
the cause of human suffering and thus the reason why we must rely only on ourselves.
the infinite extension of humanity, idealized and alienated from our essence.

desensitize us to the human misery caused by social structures we should change.

answer.text: No: no culture can impose its values on any other culture, even if those values promote human well-being.

Suppose that human well-being is the correct standard for evaluating ethical theories and judgments. Would this mean that we have to reject the cultural relativist's claim that each culture has a right to decide its own values?

answer.text: No: no culture can impose its values on any other culture, even if those values promote human well-being.
No: all cultures are different in what they value (indeed, that is what makes them different in the first place); so the destruction of cultural differences would mean the end of cultures.
Yes: but each culture would have to decide whether "promoting well-being" for its members is really what it wants.
Yes: any culture that would not satisfy basic material and social needs of all of its members would not be as good as it should be.

answer.text: No: no culture can impose its values on any other culture, even if those values promote human well-being.
No: all cultures are different in what they value (indeed, that is what makes them different in the first place); so the destruction of cultural differences would mean the end of cultures.

Yes: any culture that would not satisfy basic material and social needs of all of its members would not be as good as it should be.

Suppose that human well-being is the correct standard for evaluating ethical theories and judgments. Would this mean that we have to reject the cultural relativist's claim that each culture has a right to decide its own values?

answer.text: No: no culture can impose its values on any other culture, even if those values promote human well-being.
No: all cultures are different in what they value (indeed, that is what makes them different in the first place); so the destruction of cultural differences would mean the end of cultures.
